learning_outcomes.description: Explain the basis of machine learning and AI systems and the types of problems that are suited to address in chemical engineering.
Identify potential risks associated with the use of machine learning and AI in chemical process systems.
Collect, clean, and prepare real-world chemical engineering data for machine learning applications.
Implement and evaluate supervised learning algorithms for regression and classification of process and material property data.
Apply unsupervised learning techniques for anomaly detection and clustering of process operation data.
Implement and deploy neural networks for time series prediction of process variables.
Build, test, and demonstrate an intelligent chatbot prototype for supporting distillation plant operators.

assessments.assessment_title: Assignment-1: Data Generation and Regression Modelling with the Temperature Control Lab (TCLab)
assessments.task_description:
In this assignment, you will use the Temperature Control Laboratory (TCLab) kit to generate, process, and model real-world temperature control data. Begin by designing and executing data collection experiments using the TCLab hardware, capturing temperature readings and heater inputs under various operating conditions (e.g., step changes, ramps, disturbances) across multiple trials.

Next, clean and preprocess your collected data using pandas and NumPy, addressing missing values, outliers, and noise reduction appropriate for time-series data.

Using the cleaned dataset, develop and evaluate regression models to predict temperature responses based on heater inputs and system dynamics. Implement both linear and polynomial regression models in scikit-learn, compare their performance, and identify which best represents the TCLab’s thermal behaviour.

Document your experimental setup, data processing, modelling methodology, and engineering insights in a well-organised Jupyter notebook, and update your GitHub repository with the complete workflow, results, and model comparison.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Assignment-2: Anomaly Detection in TCLab Systems
assessments.task_description:
In this assignment, you will explore anomaly detection techniques by intentionally introducing faulty signals and abnormal operating conditions into your TCLab system to simulate real-world industrial scenarios where equipment malfunctions or sensor failures occur. Design and execute experiments to collect both normal operating data and anomalous data by creating various fault conditions such as sensor drift, heater malfunctions, or intermittent connectivity issues, ensuring you have a diverse dataset of both healthy and faulty system behaviours. Apply unsupervised anomaly detection methods including Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction. Document your fault generation methodology, model implementation, and safety analysis in a Jupyter notebook, update your GitHub repository with all anomaly detection code and datasets, and submit your complete analysis through Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.assessment_title: Assignment -3: LSTM Neural Network Development and Deployment
assessments.task_description:
Develop and train an LSTM neural network to predict dynamic system behaviour using provided time-series data. Build your model using TensorFlow/Keras with proper preprocessing, hyperparameter tuning, and performance evaluation. Deploy your trained model as an interactive web application using Streamlit that allows users to input data and visualize real-time predictions. Submit your Jupyter notebook with model development, Streamlit app code, deployed application URL, and update your GitHub repository.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.assessment_title: Final Project: RAG-Based Chatbot for Pilot Plant Distillation Column (Written Component and Oral Presentation)
assessments.due_date:
Written Component 30/01/2026 5:00 pm

Presentation Run During Exam Period 7-14 Feb 2026
assessments.category: Computer Code, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation
assessments.task_description:
Written Component - 30/01/2026 5:00 pm

Develop a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) chatbot specialised for pilot plant distillation column operations, troubleshooting, and knowledge management. The chatbot must incorporate relevant technical documentation, operating procedures, safety protocols, and troubleshooting guides for distillation processes, using vector databases and embedding models to retrieve contextually relevant information before generating responses. Implement the RAG pipeline using appropriate frameworks and a suitable language model to ensure the chatbot can answer questions about the column, operating parameters, common failures, safety procedures. The written report should describe the system architecture, implementation, evaluation, and provide supporting documentation and source citations.


Oral Presentation - School-based exam during examination period 7-14 Feb 2026

This oral presentation is part of the hurdle assessment and will be evaluated alongside the written report. Students are required to deliver a 15–20 minute in-person presentation that includes a live demonstration of their RAG chatbot. The presentation should clearly showcase the chatbot’s capabilities through real-time interactions, demonstrating how it assists operators with technical queries related to distillation column operations, troubleshooting, and safety management. It should also provide an overview of the system architecture, explain the RAG implementation, present model performance results, and discuss both limitations and potential industrial applications.

Closed-book, no written materials or calculators are permitted.
